oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Oak Ridge Boys Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with the Oak Ridge Boys (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Oak Ridge Boys; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Duane Allen of the Oak Ridge Boys discusses a time where they were called the Georgia Clob Hoppers; while being the Georgia Clob Hoppers they performed consistently for the members of the Manhattan Project -- (01:15) Allen tells about how the locals of Oak Ridge were the inspiration behind the Oak Ridge Quartet -- (02:45) Allen discusses how Wally Fowler moved the Oak Ridge Quartet to Nashville to sing on the Grand Ole Opry -- (03:18) Allen discusses how after the disbanding of the Oak Ridge Quartet, the Oak Ridge Boys got their name; Allen describes how that name stuck despite attempts to change the name -- (04:30) Allen describes why he always wants to be the Oak Ridge Boys to exemplify the young spirit -- (05:05) Allen tells of the most money he ever made coming from a song he did for Steve Sanders -- (05:50) Sanders and Collie joke about how Sanders was five years old when he began his recording career -- (06:35) Collie, Allen, and Sanders discuss the first time Sanders and the Oak Ridge Boys had worked together was in a football stadium -- (07:37) Collie has Sanders recall his time working for the Yearling (a Broadway production) and Sander tells Collie he had the same role as the film star Claude Jarman Jr. -- (08:00) Collie inquires and Sanders refutes that he was not in another Broadway performance but he had been in television and film; one film being Hurry Sundown -- (08:44) Collie addresses Allen's tenure and Allen discusses Joe Bonsall and Richard Sterban's age -- (09:33) Collie and Allen reflect on Allen's education growing up in Taylor Town, Texas -- (10:32) Allen tells about the Oak Ridge Boy's gospel upbringing leading to their ten percent return on profits -- (13:47) Collie and Allen address how Allen had the ambitions of being apart of music since his early age -- (14:58) Allen tells about the difference that animals can make on the physique -- (15:58) Allen reflects on his anticipation for a show and how he bypassed the fear -- (17:07) Sanders describes the different stages at which members joined and left the Oak Ridge Boys -- (19:21) Sander and Allen joke about how Richard Sterban and Joe Bonsall grew up in the same area -- (20:19) The Oak Ridge Boys recall how many members had been a part of the band throughout the years and Sander reveals how he had planned to create a show for the reunion -- (21:44) Allen tells about how he joined in 1966 and how the Oak Ridge Boys had only played gospel until 1977 -- (23:50) Collie recalls how Tim Spencer's first song after being 'saved' was "Cigarettes, Whiskey, and Wild, Wild Women" and Stewart Hamblen's first song, post being 'saved,' was "I Won't Go Huntin' With You Jake" -- (24:54) Allen tells about how he got a sunburn while trying to record a music video for "Gonna Take a Lot of River" -- (25:43) Allen describes the biggest fish he ever caught (a 310 lbs Tiger Shark) he caught off the Gulf of Mexico and his enjoyment in the water -- (26:55) Allen describes how he was a member of the Oak's Band for a long time before becoming a member of the Oak Ridge Boys -- (28:52) Allen reflects on the number of people interviewed after William Lee Golden was kicked out of the group and the stall of the group after he left -- (30:27) Allen and Sander praise the amount of music each other listen to and Allen tells that hit songs can change a career -- (31:33) Allen describes the three methods of making it in the recording industry: recording star, television, and performing act -- (32:55) Allen describes his thanks, briefly describes his day before a concert, and the single time they had to miss a concert -- (35:07) Collie inquires and Sander says that their demographic reflects the 'working man' and people with family values -- (36:10) Sander tells about how he was asked by his daughter's classmate to record a song for her and Sander uses this as an example of their expansive fan base and Allen describes the Oak Ridge Boys desire to entertain -- (37:39) Collie has Sander and Allen describe the exposure and feeling of winning awards -- (38:54) Collie has Allen and Sander recall a road story and Sander says that people will have to read their book -- (39:36) Sander and Allen tell about the closing numbers they consistently use and the Oak Ridge Boys address encores
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Oak Ridge Boys; Collie, Biff;
